title: Extracellular Vesicles Tracking and Quantification Using CT and Optical Imaging in Rats
procedures: Exosome production and purificationCulture human bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells in the DMEM medium, enriched with 1% L-glutamine, 1% penicillin-streptomycin-neomycin, 1% MEM-eagle non-essential amino acid, 0.04% heparin, and 10% exosome-free platelets lysate, for 3 days.Collect 10 ml medium per T75 flask when cells are at 80-90% confluency (3 x 106 cells/flask). Perform exosome isolation for a total of 110 ml medium using a standard differential centrifugation protocol, at 4 °C. In brief, centrifuge medium at 300 x g for 10 min. Centrifuge the supernatant at 2,000 x g for 10 min, re-centrifuge at 10,000 x g for 30 min, and then vacuum through a 0.22 μm filter. Centrifuge the collected supernatant at 100,000 x g for 70 min (rotor: TI-45 Beckman; 70 ml polycarbonate tubes). Wash the pellet in 70 ml PBS and centrifuge again at 100,000 x g for 70 min. Resuspend the final pellet in 200 μl sterile PBS.Exosome labeling with GNPs or PKH26Synthesize GNPsInto a single-neck round-bottom flask with stirring magnet, add 100 ml deuterium-depleted water (DDW) with a mixture of oleic acid (2.437 ml), palmitic acid (600 mg) and ethanol (15 ml, 99%).In a separate tube stir NaOH (200 mg) and DDW (30 ml) until the solution is dissolved and add into the mixture above.While stirring the solution add HAuCl4 (100 µl, 50 mg/ml), then add ascorbic acid (5 ml, 0.05 M) drop by drop, very slowly, wait additional 5 min while stirring.To the GNP solution add 15.O-(2-Carboxyethyl)-O′-(2-mercaptoethyl)heptaethylene glycol (PEG7, 2.26 x 10-3 g), followed by 1 h stirring.Achieve pH = 9 of the mixture by NaOH, and then stir for additional 1 h.Add n-hexane (80 ml), then stir the solution for 1 h.Adjust the pH to 7, using HCl solution (100 µl, 37%).

In a funnel (Separatory funnel 250 ml/glass stopcock, Sigma), perform phase separation (aqueous and organic) of the mixture at room temperature (Figure 1). Repeat the phase separation 4 times, until only aqueous solution is left.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20200530/20200530035605_5786.jpgFigure 1. Phase separation. Following 5 nm GNP formation, a funnel is used in order to separate between the organic phase (top, white) and aqueous phase (bottom, purple). This step is repeated until a pure aqueous solution that contains the GNPs is left.Add the solution with N-Hydroxysulfosuccinimide sodium salt (2.12 x 10-3 g), N-(3-Dimethylaminopropyl)-N′-ethylcarbodiimide hydrochloride (1.87 x 10-3 g), and glucose amine (D-(+)-glucosamine hydrochloride) (1.75 x 10-3 g), and stir for 3 h.Add acetone to the GNP solution (GNP:Aceton 1:4 ratio), and centrifuge for 30 min at 24 °C, 20,000 x g, gently pump out the particles that have sunk into the bottom of the tube with a pipette.Attach the particle’s veil to a vacuum pump (Millivac-Mini Vacuum Pump, Merck), to evaporate all the acetone left in the liquid.Measure the particle's concentration using ICP-OES, gold concentration should be 30-35 mg/ml.Incubate a total of 2.8 x 1010 MSC-Exo (200 μl exosomes in 1 ml saline) with GNPs (35 mg/ml, 100 μl) coated with glucose, at 37 °C for 3 h.Centrifuge the MSC-Exo at 100,000 x g for 2 h, at 4 °C. Resuspend GNP-labeled MSC-Exo in 200 µl PBS.For PKH26 labeling. Label 2.8 x 1010 MSC-Exo with PKH26 dye for 5 min at 37 °C. Wash with 70 ml PBS using ultracentrifugation for 2 h at 100,000 x g, at 4 °C. Resuspend PKH26-labeled MSC-Exo in 200 µl PBS.Spinal cord injury modelNote: All animal experimentations should be reviewed and approved by local ethical committee.Keep female Sprague Dawley rats (200-250 g) on a 12 h light/dark cycle with ad libitum access to food and water.

Ensure an acclimation period of about one week before surgery.Ensure the surgery station and tools are clean and sterile during the whole procedures to minimize the risk of infections.Anesthetize rats by intraperitoneal injections of ketamine (60-90 mg/kg) and xylazine (10-15 mg/kg) mixture, with inhalation of 1-2% isoflurane at a flow rate of 1 L/min.Place the anesthetized rats on a supine position, on a heating pad to maintain core body temperate at 37 °C.Ensure adequate anesthesia, as indicated by the absence of paw withdrawal upon pinch or corneal reflex.Apply eye ointment on both eyes to protect the eyes.Shave the fur on the back (about 5 cm x 6 cm) using an electric shaver.Palpate the prominence when the trunk of the rats is curved up, and mark the point using a permanent marker.Sterilize the area using polydine solution, followed by twice 70% ethanol solution.Inject buprenorphine (0.01-0.05 mg/kg) subcutaneously to minimize post-operative pain.Perform a 2 cm sagittal midline incision using a #10 scalpel, centering at the point identified earlier.Separate the paravertebral muscles to expose the vertebral processes.Remove the T10 vertebral body using a Rongeur to expose the spinal cord.Lift up the spinal cord using a spinal cord hook.Perform the full transection using a microscissor.Irrigate the injured field using 0.9% saline.Clean the bloods to make the surgical view clear.Verity lesion completeness by lifting up the severed spinal cord stumps and passing the spinal cord hook inside the gap to ensure no residual fibers on the bottom and lateral side of the spinal cord canal.Suture the muscle and skin layer by layer using 4.0 sutures.Gently place the rats in a temperate controlled recovery chamber, supplemented with oxygen, to allow full recovery.

Three-hour post-injury, for microCT, FAAS, and ICP studies, use a micropipetter to inject 10 µl GNP-labeled exosomes to one side of the nostrils, wait for 2 min before injecting another 10 µl dose to other side. This step repeats once again 2 min later, for a final volume of 20 µl exosomes injected to each side. For immunofluorescence studies, use a micropipetter to inject 10 µl PKH26-lableled exosomes to one side of the nostrils, wait for 2 min before injecting another 10 µl dose to other side. This step repeats once again 2 min later.Gently massage the bladder and inject buprenorphine (0.01-0.05 mg/kg) subcutaneously every 8 h.Tissue processing and microCT imaging acquisitionsTwenty-four hours after GNP-labeled exosome treatment, euthanize the rats using CO2 inside a CO2 euthanasia chamber, via a building supplied CO2 setup.Harvest the olfactory bulbs, whole brain and spinal cord tissues gently, after removing their surrounding bone structures using rongeurs and scissor.Immerse the dissected tissues in 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) overnight at 4 °C.Wash the tissues using 1x PBS for 5 min.Scan the tissues using microCT scanner (Skyscan High Resolution Model  1176  ). Imaging parameters are as follow: 45 kV tube voltage, 0.2 mm aluminum filter, and 35 μm nominal resolution. Use a modified algorithm (Feldkamp) in the GPU-accelerated SkyScanNRecon software for reconstruction. Use 25% beam hardening correction, 3% Gaussian smoothing, and ring artifact reduction. Use RGBA transfer function in the SkyScan CT-Voxel (“CTVox”) and SkyScan CT-Volume (“CTVol”) software to generate volume-rendered three-dimensional images.Tissue processing for FAAS, and ICP studiesTwenty-four hours after GNP-labeled exosome treatment, euthanize the rats using CO2.

Harvest and weigh the olfactory bulbs, whole brain, spinal cord tissues, lungs, liver, kidneys, heart and spleen (use rongeurs and scissor to remove bone structures surrounding the olfactory bulbs, whole brain and spinal cord tissues; collect whole lungs and heart in the thoracic cavity and liver, kidneys, and spleen in the abdominal cavity).For FAAS study, digest the lungs, liver, kidneys, heart, and spleen with 1 ml aqua regia acid (a mixture of nitric acid (BioLab Ltd) and hydrochloric acid (Daejung, CAS: 7647010) in a volume ratio of 1:3). Allow the solution to evaporate at room temperature, within the chemical hood for 24 h, followed by half an hour of heating to 60 °C, and dilute with DDW to 4 ml total solution. Filter smaples via 0.45 μm syringe filters. Measure gold concentrations using a linear calibration curve prepared using a solution with known gold (Au) concentrations of 0.1, 1, 2, and 5 mg/ml.For ICP study, combust the olfactory bulbs and brain, and spinal cord tissues at 550 °C for 5 h. Add 5 ml 1% HNO3 to the digested tissues and filter via 0.45 μm syringe filters. Measure gold concentrations in the samples with correlation to the gold standard curve.Tissue processing for immunofluorescence studiesTwenty-four hours after PKH26-labeled exosome treatment, euthanize the rats using CO2.Harvest the spinal cord tissues after removing the surrounding vertebral column using a rongeur and immerse the tissues in 5 ml 4% PFA at 4 °C overnight.Rinse the tissues with 1x PBS for 2 min, and immerse the tissues in 10 ml 30% sucrose solution at 4 °C overnight.Embed the tissues in optimal cutting temperature solution.Section the tissues longitudinally to 20 μm thickness.Permeabilize the tissue slices in 100 µl 0.5% Tween solution.Rinse the tissue slices thrice with 1x PBS, 5 min each wash.

Block the tissues with 100 µl 5% BSA for 1 h, at room temperature.Incubate the tissues with 50 µl primary antibodies diluted in 5% BSA, at 4 °C overnight.Rinse the tissue slices thrice with 1x PBS, 5 min each wash.Incubate the tissues with 50 µl secondary antibodies diluted in 1x PBS, at room temperature, for 1 h.Rinse the tissue slices thrice with 1x PBS, 5 min each wash.Mount the tissue slices with coverslips.Scan the tissue slices using confocal microscope (ZEISS).
